In Feb of this year my colleagues & I in the House passed a bill to eliminate the original ERA ratification deadline leftover from the 1980s to make sure there is #NoDeadlineOnEquality & all of these new state ratifications count.  We need our Senate counterparts to follow suit. https://t.co/cYEgqPphto

The ERA was first introduced into Congress in 1923 & finally passed in 1972.  We came *very close* to ratifying it in the 1980s but fell just 3 states short.  Luckily Nevada ratified it in 2017 Illinois in 2018 & Virginia in 2020 🎉— after nearly a century we are almost there!

The men who signed the U. S. Constitution on September 17 1787 in Philadelphia intentionally left many people out.  The largest group they omitted is women & to this day women do not have full constitutional protections! The ERA would fix that foundational mistake.  #ERANow

Today is #ConstitutionDay!  What’s that?  We in Congress created this holiday for all public schools & federal agencies to educate Americans on our foundational document. & I voted in favor of the House COVID-19 stimulus packages. It included critical provisions that have helped small businesses their employees and the communities they serve

Lastly the Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act of 2020 which would require 25% of personal protective equipment (PPE) to be produced in the U.S. This would promote a stronger manufacturing base in small business communities and strengthen our domestic supply chains.

I am committed to securing the funding that @NYCHA needs to improve public housing but NYCHA must act in good faith to its residents and provide critical repairs in a timely manner.   I will continue to fight tooth and nail for quality conditions for NYCHA residents.

We all have a right to safe and healthy housing.   It shouldn’t take advocates and politicians to rally for @NYCHA to ensure its apartments are habitable.   It shouldn't take a viral video to get basic repairs done.

Our nation should never be placed in this desperate position again.   We must guarantee an adequate stock of PPE at all times.   We must establish domestic supply chain incentives.  We must pass the Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act. https://t.co/3P8KLscHAg

No federal state or local entities should be forced into desperate bidding wars to provide essential workers with the equipment they need to stay safe and healthy.    No medical professional should have to wear a garbage bag because they could not get proper PPE.

The Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act creates a tax credit to assist manufacturers with the costs of developing or expanding domestic sources for the end-to-end production of PPE goods within the US.

The Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act requires 25% of that PPE be produced in the US strengthening our domestic supply chains and ensuring Americans have the tools to manufacture lifesaving supplies when the nation needs them most.
The Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act requires that the Strategic National Stockpile maintain at least enough PPE to sustain the U.S. through a year of a global pandemic.

That's why I am introducing the Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act which would guarantee an adequate stock of PPE in the Strategic National Stockpile at all times & establish domestic supply chain incentives that put Americans to work building the materials we need.

FEMA’s Supply Chain Stabilization Task Force projected a shortage of approximately 100 million gowns and 40 million N95 respirators this month.    More than 400 healthcare workers have died from coronavirus and shortages of PPE have played a significant role in this crisis.
PPE shortages remain a critical challenge in fighting the #coronavirus pandemic.    The need for the Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act could not be more urgent.

Having strong domestic production of PPE is absolutely essential to keeping Americans safe during a global pandemic.    Unfortunately too many lives have been lost unnecessarily because broken global supply chains left our essential workers without the equipment they needed.

Today I joined members of NYC’s fashion industry to unveil my new bill the Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act.    This bill is an important step toward building our domestic supply chains & making sure our nation is prepared for any future pandemic.   THREAD ⬇️ https://t.co/2hZIVqp3vT

The brutal slayings we’ve witnessed in recent weeks are almost too much to bear but now more than ever we cannot be silent or turn our heads to tragedy.   George Floyd’s life mattered Breonna Taylor’s life mattered Ahmaud Arbery’s life mattered- all #BlackLivesMatter
I stand in solidarity with George’s loved ones family and community who are demanding justice & I will do everything in my power to see that justice is served.

We can never bring George back but our nation can finally tackle this crisis that has taken the lives of so many Black people & robbed their communities. We must do more to hold officers accountable and dismantle the racist power structures that allow this violence to fester.
But it should not take a viral video or national outcry to recognize the reality of police brutality or to ensure justice is served.

While police brutality white supremacy and racism are certainly not new to our nation- footage of these incidents means more people are exposed to the violence and discrimination so many Black people face every day.
For over 400 years Black Americans have been treated as less than equal. They have been enslaved murdered profiled discriminated against and fallen victim to our criminal justice system.
I am relieved to see that this officer was finally arrested and charged but so much more must be done to stop our nation’s vicious cycle of police brutality.
The murder of George Floyd is sickening and gut-wrenching. His life was stolen by an officer whose duty was supposed to be to serve and protect not to brutalize and kill.

Today I joined Fashion for the Front Lines to thank them for producing over 1 MILLION non-surgical PPE isolation gowns!   I also announced my new bill & request for a gov study to strengthen America's PPE stockpile and our ability to produce PPE.  WATCH: https://t.co/3Q0OWP32uU
You can learn more about Fashion for the Front Lines here: https://t.co/aXex1SXgZG
Read more about this coalition & my two new initiatives to promote American manufacturing and ingenuity here: https://t.co/418C31WaAo

The fashion industry pushes the envelope & sets trends and that’s no different in the era of #COVID19.  Our work during this crisis underscores the importance of supporting #smallbiz & local manufacturers investing in NYC's fashion industry & supporting the Garment District.

When the dire need for PPE became apparent we shifted focus and formed Fashion for the Front Lines.  In partnership with @FGFH_@CareandWear local designers and the NYC Manufacturers Coalition - we’ve produced more than 1 MILLION non-surgical PPE isolation gowns.

Last year before any of us even heard about #COVID19 I brought together a group of NYC fashion designers manufacturers and industry leaders for a roundtable discussion on the nexus between technology & fashion.  I never imagined that our group’s focus would change so much.

In preparation for future pandemics the United States must have a sufficient national stockpile and a strong operation to produce our own PPE.    I don't ever want to see another nurse or medical professional wearing a garbage bag because they couldn't get proper PPE.

I am also working on a bill to better prepare our nation for future pandemics. The Made in America: Preparation for a Pandemic Act would require a percentage of the national stockpile of PPE be made in the US so that we are not forced to rely on other countries for vital PPE.

First I’m requesting a @USGAO study on how to best stabilize our country’s supply chain of PPE including harnessing American manufacturing capabilities.   We must ensure our nation is never deficient in PPE going forward.

Today I joined Fashion for the Front Lines @KayUngerDesign @CareandWear NYC designer Mi Jong Lee and @FGFH to discuss how we produced over 1 MILLION non-surgical PPE isolation gowns during #COVID19.   I also announced 2 new initiatives to save lives & save jobs.   THREAD ⬇️ https://t.co/vZndIUtYZG

#COVID19 has caused millions of businesses to close their doors & many are also being denied insurance claims.   I introduced the Pandemic Risk Insurance Act to provide a federal backstop for business interruption insurance that includes pandemic coverage. https://t.co/mNl8LGtOPu

I'm proud to have the support from more than two dozen national business and trade associations/ organizations whose members represent some of the most #COVID19 impacted businesses and employees in NYC & across the country.   More info here: https://t.co/JAi8iBwSIO

Similar to the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act that I championed to help rebuild NYC after 9/11 the federal government would serve as a backstop in the Pandemic Risk Insurance Act to ensure these policies are widely available affordable and maintain marketplace stability.

My bill would also create a Pandemic Risk Reinsurance Program that will share this burden between insurance companies and the federal government to ensure there is enough funding to cover losses caused by any future pandemics.
The Pandemic Risk Insurance Act would require insurance companies to offer business interruption insurance policies — including event cancellation — that include pandemics.

That means millions of small businesses nonprofits mom and pop shops and retailers are being denied claims from their insurance companies.   They have been left out in cold & these denials increase the likelihood they will never be financially recover from #COVID19.

While business interruption insurance typically compensates business owners when they need to shut down due to exigent circumstances – like a tornado ripping through Main Street – those policies explicitly exclude pandemics.

Today I joined @NonprofitNY @UStravel and @NRFnews to introduce the Pandemic Risk Insurance Act.  This bill will help businesses suffering from #COVID19 & protect our economy from future pandemics by providing a federal backstop for insurance that includes pandemic coverage. https://t.co/sfznC4hBA8

This is a difficult time for small businesses across the country and in #NY12 but my staff is dedicated to helping you navigate this crisis.    Please contact my office at 212-860-0606 for questions and guidance.

The Small Business Continuity Loan Program is available for businesses with fewer than 100 employees. These are interest free loans of up to $75000 and can be used to cover operational costs.  https://t.co/yU2e91xM19

The Employee Retention Program is there to help NYC’s most vulnerable mom and pops keep their employees. NYC will cover up to 40% of payroll costs for 2 months for businesses with fewer than 5 employees that have been in operation for at least 6 months. https://t.co/zapmcuolS1

NYC has also created 2 programs for small businesses located in the 5 boroughs which can demonstrate a 25% loss in business due to the COVID-19 crisis.   Information on NYC employee retention grants and the non-interest loan program available here ⬇️ https://t.co/WSYITZz1sP

Small businesses cooperatives ESOPS private non-profits independent contractors and the self-employed can access low interest disaster loans with deferred payments & receive up to $10000 to cover immediate expenses.   See more here: https://t.co/y5b6iU5mjn

FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS: The CARES Act requires @SBAgov to fast track your application to become a 7a lender so you can help small businesses in your community with Payroll Protection loans!    See more here: https://t.co/WhYVkelDi9
Franchises and hotels are included!  If your business keeps employees on payroll 100% of the loan is forgiven!   See more here: https://t.co/WhYVkelDi9

SMALL BUSINESS OWNERS: The CARES Act sets aside $349 billion in forgivable loans to help you pay employees & keep them on payroll even if they can’t come to work.    Loans are open to most businesses under 500 employees non-profits the self-employed startups & cooperatives.

Small businesses are the lifeblood of our nation & #NY12.   Here’s what the CARES Act means for #smallbiz  ✅$349 Billion in payroll loans ✅Billions in immediate disaster grants  ✅100% forgivable loans if business retains all employees  ✅Debt relief  THREAD https://t.co/lNgR5DYYiA

I've seen first hand how fragile access to banking services can be in underserved communities. That's exactly I’m committed to fighting against Trump's proposal to gut the Community Reinvestment Act.   Access to banking services should NEVER depend on your zip code.

When I was on the @NYCCouncil I represented a low-income underserved neighborhood in East Harlem. Banks were constantly pulling out of this neighborhood & they even tried to remove basic banking services like ATMS from the area.   We need a strong Community Reinvestment Act.

The witnesses we heard from today are allies with us in this fight against Trump's harmful proposal to gut Community Reinvestment Act. We must protect minority banks credit unions and CDFIs in undeserved communities.    We must fight against financial discrimination.

The Community Reinvestment Act prevents financial institutions from redlining in which banks literally draw red lines around low-income and minority communities on maps & decide not to lend — or even provide basic banking services like checking accounts — to those communities.

Today I participated in @RepGregoryMeeks' hearing about the Community Reinvestment Act. We must fight the Trump Admin's misguided proposal that undermines the CRA's purpose to ensure low-income and minority communities have equal & accessible financial services.  THREAD ⬇️ https://t.co/SivkwmtkbZ
